bugs.title: CVE-2023-27533 curl: TELNET option IAC injection [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2023-27533 curl: TELNET option IAC injection [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2023-27533 curl: TELNET option IAC injection

long_desc.thetext:
curl supports communicating using the TELNET protocol and as a part of this it offers users to pass on user name and "telnet options" for the server
negotiation. Due to lack of proper input scrubbing and without it being the documented functionality, curl would pass on user name and telnet options to the server as provided. This could allow users to pass in carefully crafted content that pass on content or do option negotiation without the application intending to do so. In particular if an application for example allows users to provide the data or parts of the data.
Not affected versions: curl < 7.7 and curl >= 8.0.0

Created curl tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2180427]


Created mingw-curl tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2180428]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  JBCS httpd 2.4.51.sp2

Via RHSA-2023:3355 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2023:3355

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  JBoss Core Services on RHEL 7
  JBoss Core Services for RHEL 8

Via RHSA-2023:3354 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2023:3354

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9

Via RHSA-2023:6679 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2023:6679

More information about this security flaw is available in the following bug:

http://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2179062

Disclaimer: Community trackers are created by Red Hat Product Security team on a best effort basis. Package maintainers are required to ascertain if the flaw indeed affects their package, before starting the update process.

bugs.title: CVE-2023-27535 curl: FTP too eager connection reuse [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2023-27535 curl: FTP too eager connection reuse [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2023-27535 curl: FTP too eager connection reuse

long_desc.thetext: libcurl keeps previously used connections in a connection pool for subsequent transfers to reuse if one of them matches the setup. However, several FTP settings were left out from the configuration match checks, making them match too easily. The settings in questions are `CURLOPT_FTP_ACCOUNT`, `CURLOPT_FTP_ALTERNATIVE_TO_USER`, `CURLOPT_FTP_SSL_CCC` and `CURLOPT_USE_SSL` level.

Created curl tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2180429]


Created mingw-curl tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2180430]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9

Via RHSA-2023:2650 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2023:2650

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2023:3106 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2023:3106

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2023-27535

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.6 Extended Update Support

Via RHSA-2024:0428 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2024:0428

bugs.title: CVE-2023-27536 curl: GSS delegation too eager connection re-use [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2023-27536 curl: GSS delegation too eager connection re-use [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2023-27536 curl: GSS delegation too eager connection re-use

long_desc.thetext: libcurl would reuse a previously created connection even when the GSS delegation (`CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION`) option had been changed that could have changed the user's permissions in a second transfer. libcurl keeps previously used connections in a connection pool for subsequent transfers to reuse if one of them matches the setup. However, this GSS delegation setting was left out from the configuration match checks, making them match too easily, affecting krb5/kerberos/negotiate/GSSAPI transfers.

Created curl tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2180431]


Created mingw-curl tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2180432]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2023:4523 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2023:4523

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9

Via RHSA-2023:6679 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2023:6679

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.6 Extended Update Support

Via RHSA-2024:0428 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2024:0428

More information about this security flaw is available in the following bug:

http://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2179092

bugs.title: CVE-2023-27534 curl: SFTP path ~ resolving discrepancy [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2023-27534 curl: SFTP path ~ resolving discrepancy [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2023-27534 curl: SFTP path ~ resolving discrepancy

long_desc.thetext:
curl supports SFTP transfers. curl's SFTP implementation offers a special feature in the path component of URLs: a tilde (`~`) character as the first
path element in the path to denotes a path relative to the user's home directory. This is supported because of wording in the [once proposed
to-become RFC draft](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-secsh-scp-sftp-ssh-uri-04) that was to dictate how SFTP URLs work. Due to a bug, the handling of the tilde in SFTP path did however not only replace it when it is used stand-alone as the first path element but also wrongly when used as a mere prefix in the first element. Using a path like `/~2/foo` when accessing a server using the user `dan` (with home directory `/home/dan`) would then quite suprisingly access the file `/home/dan2/foo`. This can be taken advantage of to circumvent filtering or worse.

Created curl tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2180434]


Created mingw-curl tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2180436]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  JBCS httpd 2.4.51.sp2

Via RHSA-2023:3355 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2023:3355

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  JBoss Core Services on RHEL 7
  JBoss Core Services for RHEL 8

Via RHSA-2023:3354 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2023:3354

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9

Via RHSA-2023:6679 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2023:6679

More information about this security flaw is available in the following bug:

http://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2179069

Disclaimer: Community trackers are created by Red Hat Product Security team on a best effort basis. Package maintainers are required to ascertain if the flaw indeed affects their package, before starting the update process.

bugs.title: CVE-2023-27538 curl: SSH connection too eager reuse still [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2023-27538 curl: SSH connection too eager reuse still [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2023-27538 curl: SSH connection too eager reuse still

long_desc.thetext: libcurl would reuse a previously created connection even when an SSH related option had been changed that should have prohibited reuse. libcurl keeps previously used connections in a connection pool for subsequent transfers to reuse if one of them matches the setup. However, two SSH settings were left out from the configuration match checks, making them match too easily.

Created curl tracking bugs for this issue:

title: curl-7.87.0-7.fc38
